docs.title: Welcome to InfraIQ
docs.text:
Migration as a Service — Migrate from Heroku to AWS in hours, not months.

InfraIQ is a comprehensive DevOps automation platform that transforms weeks of manual infrastructure work into automated processes completed in minutes.

  • MigrateIQ

    Automated cloud migration from Heroku, AWS, GCP, or Azure.

    Learn more

  • VerifyIQ

    Infrastructure verification, security scanning, and drift detection.

    Learn more

  • CodifyIQ

    Transform existing infrastructure into Infrastructure as Code.

    Learn more

  • ComplyIQ

    Continuous compliance automation for SOC2, ISO27001, HIPAA.

    Learn more

  • DataIQ

    Zero-downtime database migrations with self-healing.

    Learn more

  • SecureIQ

    Secret discovery and management for migrations.

    Learn more

  • Tessera

    AI-powered monolith to microservices transformation.

    Learn more

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Install InfraIQ with a single command:

curl -sSL https://install.autonops.io | bash

Verify the installation:

infraiq --version
infraiq doctor
infraiq info

docs.title: Battle-Tested Patterns
docs.text:
Built from real-world experience:

  • Spotify — Scaled podcast platform to 1.1B monthly downloads
  • Capital One — First fully cloud-based bank
  • Point Digital Finance — $4B fintech Heroku → AWS migration
  • NSA — DoD compliance and security requirements

docs.title: Real ROI
docs.text: Scenario Manual With InfraIQ Savings Heroku → AWS migration 2-3 months 1 week 92% Security audit (100 resources) 1 week 2 hours 95% Codify 100 AWS resources 2 weeks 2 hours 99% SOC2 evidence collection 2 weeks 2 hours 95% Database migration (100GB) 2-3 days 2-4 hours 95%

docs.text:
InfraIQ is currently in beta through Q1 2026.

Join the Beta View on GitHub

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text: All notable changes to InfraIQ will be documented here.

docs.title: Added
docs.text:
• Tessera — AI-powered monolith decomposition
  • Beta expiration system (Q1 2026)
  • Telemetry infrastructure
  • Unified migrate-and-transform command

docs.title: Changed
docs.text:
• Updated documentation structure
  • Improved error messages

docs.title: Fixed
docs.text: • Various bug fixes and improvements

docs.title: Added
docs.text:
• SecureIQ — Secret discovery and management
  • DataIQ — Zero-downtime database migrations
  • Heroku to AWS migration improvements

docs.title: Added
docs.text:
• Initial release
  • VerifyIQ — Infrastructure verification
  • CodifyIQ — Infrastructure as Code generation

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to InfraIQ!

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Clone your fork
  3. Create a feature branch
  4. Make your changes
  5. Submit a pull request

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/autonops/infraIQ.git
cd infraIQ

# Create virtual environment
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate

# Install in development mode
pip install -e ".[dev]"

# Run tests
pytest

# Run linting
black .
flake8 .
mypy .

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
• We use Black for formatting
  • We use flake8 for linting
  • We use mypy for type checking
  • All public functions should have docstrings

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Update documentation for any new features
  2. Add tests for new functionality
  3. Ensure all tests pass
  4. Update the CHANGELOG
  5. Request review from maintainers

docs.title: Reporting Issues
docs.text:
Please use GitHub Issues to report:

  • Bugs
  • Feature requests
  • Documentation improvements

docs.title: Questions?
docs.text:
• Email: jason@autonops.io
  • GitHub: @autonops

docs.title: Third-Party Licenses
docs.text:
InfraIQ uses the following open-source libraries:

  • Click — BSD-3-Clause
  • Rich — MIT
  • Boto3 — Apache-2.0
  • PyYAML — MIT

See the full list in requirements.txt.

docs.title: CLI Reference
docs.text: Complete command-line reference for InfraIQ.

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text:
infraiq [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]
Option Description --version Show version --help Show help --verbose Enable verbose output --format Output format (json, yaml, table)

docs.title: infraiq
docs.text:
# Show suite info
infraiq info

# Run diagnostics
infraiq doctor

# Combined migration + transformation
infraiq migrate-and-transform --heroku-app NAME --target aws

docs.title: migrate
docs.text:
# Scan source infrastructure
infraiq migrate scan PROVIDER [OPTIONS]
  --app-name NAME      Heroku app name
  --team NAME          Heroku team
  --region REGION      AWS/GCP region
  --output FILE        Output file

# Map to target provider
infraiq migrate map INPUT TARGET [OPTIONS]
  --preferences FILE   Custom mapping preferences
  --output FILE        Output file

# Generate Terraform
infraiq migrate generate INPUT [OPTIONS]
  --output DIR         Output directory

docs.title: verify
docs.text:
# Scan infrastructure
infraiq verify scan [OPTIONS]
  --provider NAME      Cloud provider
  --region REGION      Region(s) to scan
  --output FILE        Output file

# Analyze results
infraiq verify analyze INPUT [OPTIONS]
  --severity LEVELS    Filter by severity
  --category CATS      Filter by category

# Validate Terraform
infraiq verify validate DIR [OPTIONS]
  --rules FILE         Custom rules

docs.title: codify
docs.text:
# Scan existing resources
infraiq codify scan PROVIDER [OPTIONS]
  --region REGION      Region to scan
  --types TYPES        Resource types
  --output FILE        Output file

# Generate Terraform
infraiq codify generate INPUT [OPTIONS]
  --output DIR         Output directory
  --include-import     Generate import script

docs.title: complyiq
docs.text:
# Quick compliance check
infraiq complyiq quickscan [OPTIONS]
  --framework NAME     Compliance framework

# Full evidence collection
infraiq complyiq scan [OPTIONS]
  --provider NAME      Cloud provider
  --framework NAME     Compliance framework
  --bucket NAME        S3 bucket for evidence

# Export evidence package
infraiq complyiq export [OPTIONS]
  --bucket NAME        Source bucket
  --framework NAME     Framework
  --output FILE        Output zip file

docs.title: dataiq
docs.text:
# Discover database
infraiq dataiq discover [OPTIONS]
  --source URL         Source database URL
  --output FILE        Output file

# Plan migration
infraiq dataiq plan [OPTIONS]
  --assessment FILE    Discovery output
  --target TYPE        Target database type
  --output FILE        Output file

# Execute migration
infraiq dataiq migrate [OPTIONS]
  --plan FILE          Migration plan
  --strategy NAME      Migration strategy
  --self-heal          Enable self-healing
  --auto-cutover       Automatic cutover

# Validate migration
infraiq dataiq validate [OPTIONS]
  --source URL         Source database
  --target URL         Target database

docs.title: secureiq
docs.text:
# Scan for secrets
infraiq secureiq scan [OPTIONS]
  --provider NAME      Cloud provider
  --input FILE         Infrastructure scan
  --output FILE        Output file

# Audit compliance
infraiq secureiq audit [OPTIONS]
  --manifest FILE      Secrets manifest
  --framework NAME     Compliance framework

# Generate checklist
infraiq secureiq checklist [OPTIONS]
  --manifest FILE      Secrets manifest
  --target PROVIDER    Target provider
  --output FILE        Output file

docs.title: tessera
docs.text:
# Analyze monolith
infraiq tessera analyze [OPTIONS]
  --source DIR         Source directory
  --heroku-app NAME    Heroku app name
  --database-url URL   Database URL
  --use-ai             Enable AI analysis
  --output FILE        Output file

# Design microservices
infraiq tessera design [OPTIONS]
  --analysis FILE      Analysis output
  --pattern NAME       Decomposition pattern
  --target-services N  Target number of services
  --interactive        Interactive mode
  --output FILE        Output file

# Generate scaffolds
infraiq tessera craft [OPTIONS]
  --mosaic FILE        Design output
  --framework NAME     Web framework
  --include-docker     Include Dockerfiles
  --include-ci         Include CI configs
  --output DIR         Output directory

# Validate architecture
infraiq tessera validate [OPTIONS]
  --mosaic FILE        Design output
  --check CHECKS       Validation checks

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description INFRAIQ_TELEMETRY Enable/disable telemetry INFRAIQ_CONFIG Config file path AWS_REGION Default AWS region AWS_PROFILE AWS credentials profile HEROKU_API_KEY Heroku API key

docs.title: Python API
docs.text: Use InfraIQ programmatically in your Python applications.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
The Python API is available when InfraIQ is installed via the install script:

curl -sSL https://install.autonops.io | bash

Then activate the virtual environment to access the API:

source ~/.infraiq/venv/bin/activate

Docker Users

The Python API is not available when using the Docker distribution. Use the CLI commands instead, or install via the install script for programmatic access.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
from infraiq import MigrateIQ, VerifyIQ

# Scan Heroku app
migrate = MigrateIQ()
scan_result = migrate.scan_heroku("my-app")

# Map to AWS
plan = migrate.map_to_aws(scan_result)

# Generate Terraform
migrate.generate_terraform(plan, output_dir="./terraform")

docs.title: MigrateIQ
docs.text:
from infraiq import MigrateIQ

migrate = MigrateIQ()

# Scan
result = migrate.scan_heroku(app_name="my-app")
result = migrate.scan_aws(region="us-east-1")

# Map
plan = migrate.map_to_aws(result, preferences={})
plan = migrate.map_to_gcp(result)

# Generate
migrate.generate_terraform(plan, output_dir="./terraform")

docs.title: VerifyIQ
docs.text:
from infraiq import VerifyIQ

verify = VerifyIQ()

# Scan
report = verify.scan_aws(region="us-east-1")

# Filter findings
critical = report.filter(severity="critical")
security = report.filter(category="security")

# Export
report.to_json("report.json")

docs.title: CodifyIQ
docs.text:
from infraiq import CodifyIQ

codify = CodifyIQ()

# Discover resources
resources = codify.scan_aws(region="us-east-1")

# Generate Terraform
codify.generate_terraform(resources, output_dir="./terraform")

docs.title: Tessera
docs.text:
from infraiq import Tessera

tessera = Tessera()

# Analyze
analysis = tessera.analyze(
    source_dir="./myapp",
    use_ai=True
)

# Design
mosaic = tessera.design(
    analysis,
    pattern="hybrid",
    target_services=5
)

# Generate
tessera.craft(
    mosaic,
    framework="fastapi",
    output_dir="./services"
)

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
from infraiq import MigrateIQ
from infraiq.exceptions import (
    ScanError,
    ValidationError,
    ProviderError
)

migrate = MigrateIQ()

try:
    result = migrate.scan_heroku("my-app")
except ProviderError as e:
    print(f"Provider error: {e}")
except ScanError as e:
    print(f"Scan failed: {e}")

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
from infraiq import Config

# Load from file
config = Config.from_file("~/.infraiq/config.yaml")

# Or configure programmatically
config = Config(
    aws_region="us-east-1",
    output_format="json",
    telemetry=False
)

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• CLI Reference — Command-line usage
  • Configuration — Configuration options

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: InfraIQ can be configured through environment variables, configuration files, or command-line options.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Create ~/.infraiq/config.yaml:

# Default cloud provider
default_provider: aws

# AWS settings
aws:
  region: us-east-1
  profile: default

# Heroku settings
heroku:
  team: my-team

# Output preferences
output:
  format: json  # json, yaml, table
  color: true
  verbose: false

# Telemetry
telemetry:
  enabled: true

# Migration defaults
migration:
  target_provider: aws
  include_monitoring: true
  include_logging: true

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
All settings can also be configured via environment variables:

Variable Description Default INFRAIQ_TELEMETRY Enable/disable telemetry true INFRAIQ_OUTPUT_FORMAT Output format (json/yaml/table) json INFRAIQ_VERBOSE Verbose output false INFRAIQ_CONFIG Path to config file ~/.infraiq/config.yaml AWS_REGION Default AWS region us-east-1 AWS_PROFILE AWS credentials profile default

Example:

export INFRAIQ_TELEMETRY=false
export INFRAIQ_OUTPUT_FORMAT=yaml
export AWS_REGION=us-west-2

docs.title: Command-Line Options
docs.text:
Most settings can be overridden per-command:

# Override output format
infraiq verify scan --provider aws --format yaml

# Override region
infraiq codify scan aws --region eu-west-1

# Enable verbose output
infraiq migrate scan heroku --verbose

docs.title: AWS
docs.text:
InfraIQ uses the standard AWS credential chain:

  1. Environment variables (AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY)
  2. Shared credentials file (~/.aws/credentials)
  3. IAM role (when running on AWS)
# Option 1: Environment variables
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=AKIAIOSFODNN7EXAMPLE
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=wJalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG/bPxRfiCYEXAMPLEKEY
export AWS_REGION=us-east-1

# Option 2: AWS CLI profile
aws configure --profile infraiq
export AWS_PROFILE=infraiq

docs.title: Heroku
docs.text:
# Login to Heroku
heroku login

# Or use API key
export HEROKU_API_KEY=your-api-key

docs.title: Google Cloud
docs.text:
# Authenticate
gcloud auth login
gcloud auth application-default login

# Set project
gcloud config set project my-project-id

docs.title: Azure
docs.text:
# Login
az login

# Set subscription
az account set --subscription "My Subscription"

docs.title: MigrateIQ
docs.text:
# ~/.infraiq/config.yaml
migration:
  # Default target provider
  target_provider: aws

  # Service mapping preferences
  preferences:
    web_dyno: ecs-fargate  # or app-runner, ec2
    database: aurora       # or rds, none
    cache: elasticache     # or none

  # Include optional components
  include:
    monitoring: true
    logging: true
    alerts: true
    backups: true

docs.title: VerifyIQ
docs.text:
verify:
  # Severity threshold for failures
  fail_on: high  # low, medium, high, critical

  # Scan categories
  categories:
    - security
    - cost
    - reliability
    - compliance

  # Skip specific rules
  skip_rules:
    - AWS_S3_PUBLIC_READ

docs.title: ComplyIQ
docs.text:
comply:
  # Default framework
  framework: soc2

  # Evidence storage
  evidence:
    bucket: my-compliance-bucket
    prefix: evidence/

  # Notification on findings
  notify:
    email: security@company.com
    slack_webhook: https://hooks.slack.com/...

docs.title: Tessera
docs.text:
tessera:
  # LLM provider for AI analysis
  llm:
    provider: openai  # openai, anthropic, bedrock
    model: gpt-4

  # Decomposition preferences
  decomposition:
    pattern: hybrid  # domain, data, team, hybrid
    min_services: 3
    max_services: 10

docs.title: Precedence
docs.text:
Configuration is applied in this order (later overrides earlier):

  1. Built-in defaults
  2. Config file (~/.infraiq/config.yaml)
  3. Environment variables
  4. Command-line options

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Tools Overview — Learn about all InfraIQ tools
  • Quick Start — Run your first migration

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: InfraIQ can be installed via Docker (recommended) or the install script.

docs.title: Option 1: Docker (Recommended)
docs.text: Docker provides a consistent, isolated environment with no dependency conflicts.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Docker — Install Docker

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
# Pull the image
docker pull autonops/infraiq:latest

# Create persistent volume for configuration
docker volume create infraiq-data

docs.title: Set Up Aliases
docs.text:
Add to your ~/.zshrc or ~/.bashrc:

# InfraIQ Docker aliases
alias infraiq='docker run --rm -v $(pwd):/workspace -v ~/.aws:/home/infraiq/.aws:ro -v infraiq-data:/home/infraiq/.infraiq autonops/infraiq'
alias verify='infraiq verify'
alias codify='infraiq codify'
alias migrate='infraiq migrate'
alias complyiq='infraiq complyiq'
alias dataiq='infraiq dataiq'
alias secureiq='infraiq secureiq'
alias tessera='infraiq tessera'

Then reload your shell:

source ~/.zshrc  # or source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
infraiq --help
infraiq doctor
infraiq info

docs.title: Option 2: Binary Download
docs.text: Download a standalone executable with zero dependencies.

docs.title: Download
docs.text: Platform Download macOS (Apple Silicon) infraiq-macos-arm64.tar.gz macOS (Intel) infraiq-macos-x64.tar.gz Linux (x64) infraiq-linux-x64.tar.gz Linux (ARM64) infraiq-linux-arm64.tar.gz

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
# Example: macOS Apple Silicon
curl -LO https://github.com/autonops/infraIQ/releases/latest/download/infraiq-macos-arm64.tar.gz
tar -xzf infraiq-macos-arm64.tar.gz
sudo mv infraiq /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
infraiq --version
infraiq --help

docs.title: Option 3: Install Script
docs.text: For beta users, the install script automates setup.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.9+ — Check with python3 --version
  • Git — For cloning the repository

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
curl -sSL https://install.autonops.io | bash

This script will:

  1. Check for Python 3.9+
  2. Clone the InfraIQ repository
  3. Set up a virtual environment
  4. Configure your PATH
  5. Download the telemetry daemon

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
infraiq --version
infraiq doctor
infraiq info

Expected output from infraiq info:

🚀 InfraIQ Suite - Complete Infrastructure Management Platform
============================================================

📦 Available Tools:

  VerifyIQ        ✅ Installed     - Infrastructure verification
  CodifyIQ        ✅ Installed     - Infrastructure as Code
  MigrateIQ       ✅ Installed     - Cloud migration
  ComplyIQ        ✅ Installed     - Compliance automation
  DataIQ          ✅ Installed     - Database migration
  SecureIQ        ✅ Installed     - Secret management
  Tessera         ✅ Installed     - Microservices transformation

docs.title: Cloud Provider Setup
docs.text: InfraIQ works with multiple cloud providers. Configure the ones you need:

docs.title: AWS
docs.text:
# Install AWS CLI
brew install awscli  # macOS

# Configure credentials
aws configure

For Docker users, your ~/.aws directory is automatically mounted read-only.

docs.title: Heroku
docs.text:
# Install Heroku CLI
brew tap heroku/brew && brew install heroku  # macOS

# Login
heroku login

docs.title: Google Cloud
docs.text:
# Install gcloud CLI
brew install google-cloud-sdk  # macOS

# Authenticate
gcloud auth login
gcloud config set project YOUR_PROJECT_ID

docs.title: Azure
docs.text:
# Install Azure CLI
brew install azure-cli  # macOS

# Login
az login

docs.title: Terraform Setup
docs.text:
InfraIQ generates Terraform configurations. Install Terraform to apply them:

# macOS
brew tap hashicorp/tap
brew install hashicorp/tap/terraform

# Verify
terraform --version

docs.title: Telemetry
docs.text:
InfraIQ collects anonymous usage data to improve the product. No credentials, personal information, or infrastructure details are collected.

To opt out:

export INFRAIQ_TELEMETRY=false

Or add to your shell profile (~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc):

echo 'export INFRAIQ_TELEMETRY=false' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Docker: Permission Denied
docs.text:
If you get permission errors with Docker:

# Ensure Docker daemon is running
docker info

# On Linux, add your user to the docker group
sudo usermod -aG docker $USER
# Then log out and back in

docs.title: Docker: AWS Credentials Not Found
docs.text:
Ensure your ~/.aws directory exists and contains valid credentials:

ls ~/.aws/credentials
aws sts get-caller-identity  # Test credentials work

docs.title: Install Script: Python Version Issues
docs.text:
If you see errors about Python version:

# Check your Python version
python3 --version

# If < 3.9, install a newer version
brew install python@3.11  # macOS

docs.title: Command Not Found
docs.text:
If infraiq command is not found after installation:

# For install script users, check your PATH
echo $PATH | grep infraiq

# Reload your shell config
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Quick Start Guide — Your first migration in 5 minutes
  • Configuration — Customize InfraIQ settings
  • Tools Overview — Learn about all 7 tools

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with InfraIQ in 5 minutes.

docs.title: Your First Migration
docs.text: Let's migrate a Heroku app to AWS. This example walks through the complete workflow.

docs.title: Step 1: Scan Your Heroku App
docs.text:
infraiq migrate scan heroku --app-name my-production-app --output scan.json

This discovers:

  • Web dynos and workers
  • Add-ons (Postgres, Redis, etc.)
  • Environment variables
  • Connected services

docs.title: Step 2: Map to AWS Services
docs.text:
infraiq migrate map scan.json aws --output migration-plan.json

InfraIQ intelligently maps Heroku services to AWS equivalents:

Heroku AWS Web Dyno ECS Fargate / App Runner Postgres RDS Aurora Redis ElastiCache Worker ECS Task Scheduler EventBridge + Lambda

docs.title: Step 3: Generate Terraform
docs.text:
infraiq migrate generate migration-plan.json --output ./terraform

This creates production-ready Terraform including:

  • VPC with public/private subnets
  • ECS cluster and services
  • RDS database
  • Security groups
  • IAM roles
  • Load balancer

docs.title: Step 4: Review and Apply
docs.text:
cd terraform

# Review the plan
terraform init
terraform plan

# Apply when ready
terraform apply

docs.title: Verify Infrastructure Security
docs.text:
# Scan AWS for security issues
infraiq verify scan --provider aws --output report.json

# View the report
infraiq verify analyze report.json

docs.title: Codify Existing Infrastructure
docs.text:
# Discover manually-created resources
infraiq codify scan aws --region us-east-1 --output scan.json

# Generate Terraform for them
infraiq codify generate scan.json --output ./terraform

# Import into Terraform state
cd terraform && ./import.sh

docs.title: SOC2 Evidence Collection
docs.text:
# Quick compliance scan
infraiq complyiq quickscan

# Full SOC2 evidence collection
infraiq complyiq scan --provider aws --framework soc2 --bucket my-evidence-bucket

docs.title: Analyze a Monolith
docs.text:
# Analyze codebase for service boundaries
infraiq tessera analyze --source . --output analysis.json

# Design microservices architecture
infraiq tessera design --analysis analysis.json --pattern hybrid --output mosaic.yaml

# Generate service scaffolds
infraiq tessera craft --mosaic mosaic.yaml --framework fastapi --output ./services

docs.title: Unified Workflow
docs.text:
The real power comes from combining tools. Here's a complete modernization workflow:

# 1. Verify current state
infraiq verify scan --provider heroku --output current-state.json

# 2. Analyze monolith structure  
infraiq tessera analyze --source . --output tessera-analysis.json

# 3. Design microservices
infraiq tessera design --analysis tessera-analysis.json --output mosaic.yaml

# 4. Discover secrets
infraiq secureiq scan --provider heroku --input current-state.json --output secrets.yaml

# 5. Plan migration with transformation
infraiq migrate map current-state.json aws \
  --tessera-mosaic mosaic.yaml \
  --secrets-manifest secrets.yaml \
  --output migration-plan.json

# 6. Generate everything
infraiq tessera craft --mosaic mosaic.yaml --output ./services
infraiq migrate generate migration-plan.json --output ./infrastructure

# 7. Deploy
cd infrastructure && terraform apply

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• MigrateIQ — Deep dive into migration capabilities
  • VerifyIQ — Security and compliance scanning
  • Tessera — Monolith decomposition guide
  • Heroku to AWS Guide — Complete migration walkthrough

docs.title: Heroku to AWS Migration Guide
docs.text: A complete walkthrough for migrating from Heroku to AWS.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This guide covers migrating a typical Heroku application to AWS, including:

  • Web dynos → ECS Fargate
  • Postgres → Aurora
  • Redis → ElastiCache
  • Environment variables → Secrets Manager

Estimated time: 2-4 hours (vs. 2-3 months manually)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• AWS CLI configured
  • Heroku CLI logged in
  • Terraform installed
  • InfraIQ installed

docs.title: Step 1: Scan Heroku
docs.text:
infraiq migrate scan heroku --app-name my-production-app --output scan.json

Review the scan results:

cat scan.json | jq '.services'

docs.title: Step 2: Map to AWS
docs.text:
infraiq migrate map scan.json aws --output migration-plan.json

Review service mappings:

cat migration-plan.json | jq '.mappings'

docs.title: Step 3: Generate Terraform
docs.text: infraiq migrate generate migration-plan.json --output ./terraform

docs.title: Step 4: Configure Variables
docs.text:
Edit terraform/terraform.tfvars:

# Database
db_password = "your-secure-password"

# Application secrets
environment_variables = {
  SECRET_KEY_BASE = "your-secret-key"
  # Copy from Heroku config vars
}

docs.title: Step 5: Deploy Infrastructure
docs.text:
cd terraform
terraform init
terraform plan
terraform apply

docs.title: Step 6: Migrate Database
docs.text:
Use DataIQ for zero-downtime migration:

infraiq dataiq migrate \
  --source $HEROKU_DATABASE_URL \
  --target $AWS_DATABASE_URL \
  --strategy blue-green

docs.title: Step 7: Deploy Application
docs.text:
# Build and push Docker image
docker build -t my-app .
docker tag my-app:latest $ECR_REPO:latest
docker push $ECR_REPO:latest

# Update ECS service
aws ecs update-service --cluster my-cluster --service my-service --force-new-deployment

docs.title: Step 8: DNS Cutover
docs.text:
1. Update DNS to point to AWS load balancer
  2. Monitor for errors
  3. Scale down Heroku after validation

docs.title: Step 9: Validate
docs.text:
infraiq verify scan --provider aws --output post-migration.json
infraiq verify analyze post-migration.json

docs.title: Rollback Plan
docs.text:
If issues occur:

  1. Switch DNS back to Heroku
  2. Heroku app should still be running
  3. Investigate and fix AWS issues
  4. Retry cutover

docs.title: Cost Comparison
docs.text: Component Heroku AWS 2x Standard-2X $100/mo ~$50/mo (Fargate) Postgres Standard $50/mo ~$30/mo (RDS) Redis Premium $30/mo ~$15/mo (ElastiCache) Total $180/mo ~$95/mo

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• VerifyIQ — Ongoing security monitoring
  • ComplyIQ — SOC2 compliance

docs.title: Monolith Decomposition Guide
docs.text: Transform your monolith into microservices with Tessera.

docs.title: When to Decompose
docs.text:
Consider decomposition when:

  • Team is growing and stepping on each other
  • Deployments are slow and risky
  • Scaling is difficult (all or nothing)
  • Technology choices are locked in
  • Testing takes too long

docs.title: 1. Analyze
docs.text:
infraiq tessera analyze \
  --source . \
  --database-url $DATABASE_URL \
  --use-ai \
  --output analysis.json

docs.title: 2. Design
docs.text:
infraiq tessera design \
  --analysis analysis.json \
  --pattern hybrid \
  --target-services 5-7 \
  --output mosaic.yaml

docs.title: 3. Review
docs.text:
# Interactive review
infraiq tessera design \
  --analysis analysis.json \
  --interactive \
  --output mosaic-final.yaml

docs.title: 4. Generate
docs.text:
infraiq tessera craft \
  --mosaic mosaic-final.yaml \
  --framework fastapi \
  --include-docker \
  --include-ci \
  --output ./services

docs.title: 5. Validate
docs.text:
infraiq tessera validate \
  --mosaic mosaic-final.yaml \
  --check dependencies,data,performance

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Start with domain analysis — Understand your business domains
  2. Identify seams — Look for natural boundaries
  3. Data first — Plan data ownership before splitting
  4. Incremental — Extract one service at a time
  5. Keep the monolith running — Strangler fig pattern

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Tessera — Full documentation
  • Heroku to AWS Guide — Combine with migration

docs.title: SOC2 Compliance Guide
docs.text: Automate SOC2 evidence collection with ComplyIQ.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
SOC2 (Service Organization Control 2) is a compliance framework for service providers. ComplyIQ automates evidence collection for:

  • Security — Protection against unauthorized access
  • Availability — System availability and uptime
  • Processing Integrity — Accurate and timely processing
  • Confidentiality — Protection of confidential information
  • Privacy — Personal information handling

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Run quick compliance check
infraiq complyiq quickscan --framework soc2

docs.title: Full Evidence Collection
docs.text:
# Create evidence bucket
aws s3 mb s3://my-company-soc2-evidence

# Collect evidence
infraiq complyiq scan \
  --provider aws \
  --framework soc2 \
  --bucket my-company-soc2-evidence

docs.title: Access Control
docs.text:
• IAM policies and roles
  • MFA configuration
  • Password policies
  • Access reviews

docs.title: Encryption
docs.text:
• Data at rest encryption
  • Data in transit (TLS)
  • Key management

docs.title: Logging & Monitoring
docs.text:
• CloudTrail configuration
  • CloudWatch alarms
  • Log retention policies

docs.title: Network Security
docs.text:
• VPC configuration
  • Security groups
  • Network ACLs

docs.title: Audit Preparation
docs.text:
# Export evidence package
infraiq complyiq export \
  --bucket my-company-soc2-evidence \
  --framework soc2 \
  --output soc2-evidence-2025-Q1.zip

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• ComplyIQ — Full documentation
  • VerifyIQ — Security scanning

docs.title: CodifyIQ
docs.text: Transform existing infrastructure into Infrastructure as Code.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
CodifyIQ converts manually-created cloud resources into Terraform:

  • Discovers resources created via console (ClickOps)
  • Analyzes dependencies between resources
  • Generates Terraform with import scripts
  • Enables GitOps without disruption

docs.title: Scan
docs.text:
# Scan AWS
infraiq codify scan aws --region us-east-1 -o scan.json

# Scan multiple regions
infraiq codify scan aws --region us-east-1,us-west-2 -o scan.json

# Filter by resource type
infraiq codify scan aws --types ec2,rds,s3 -o scan.json

docs.title: Analyze
docs.text:
# View discovered resources
infraiq codify analyze scan.json

# Show dependency graph
infraiq codify analyze scan.json --show-dependencies

docs.title: Generate
docs.text:
# Generate Terraform
infraiq codify generate scan.json --output ./terraform

# Generate with import script
infraiq codify generate scan.json --output ./terraform --include-import

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
# 1. Discover existing resources
infraiq codify scan aws --region us-east-1 -o scan.json

# 2. Review what was found
infraiq codify analyze scan.json

# 3. Generate Terraform
infraiq codify generate scan.json --output ./terraform

# 4. Import into state
cd terraform
./import.sh

# 5. Verify no changes
terraform plan  # Should show "No changes"

docs.title: AWS
docs.text:
• EC2 instances, ASGs, Launch Templates
  • VPCs, Subnets, Security Groups
  • RDS, Aurora, DynamoDB
  • S3 buckets
  • Lambda functions
  • ECS clusters and services
  • IAM roles and policies
  • And more...

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• VerifyIQ — Validate your IaC
  • MigrateIQ — Migrate to new infrastructure

docs.title: ComplyIQ
docs.text: Continuous compliance automation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
ComplyIQ automates compliance monitoring and evidence collection:

  • Monitors infrastructure for SOC2, ISO27001, HIPAA compliance
  • Collects evidence automatically for audits
  • Stores in organized S3 structure with metadata
  • Exports audit-ready evidence packages

docs.title: Quick Scan
docs.text:
# Quick compliance check
infraiq complyiq quickscan

# Scan specific framework
infraiq complyiq quickscan --framework soc2

docs.title: Full Scan
docs.text:
# Full SOC2 evidence collection
infraiq complyiq scan \
  --provider aws \
  --framework soc2 \
  --bucket my-evidence-bucket

# HIPAA compliance
infraiq complyiq scan \
  --provider aws \
  --framework hipaa \
  --bucket my-evidence-bucket

docs.title: Export
docs.text:
# Export evidence package for auditors
infraiq complyiq export \
  --bucket my-evidence-bucket \
  --framework soc2 \
  --output evidence-package.zip

docs.title: Supported Frameworks
docs.text:
• SOC2 — Type I and Type II
  • ISO27001 — Information security
  • HIPAA — Healthcare data protection
  • PCI-DSS — Payment card industry
  • GDPR — Data privacy (EU)

docs.title: SOC2
docs.text:
• Access control configurations
  • Encryption settings
  • Logging and monitoring
  • Network security
  • Change management

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• VerifyIQ — Security scanning
  • SOC2 Compliance Guide

docs.title: DataIQ
docs.text: Zero-downtime database migrations.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
DataIQ handles complex database migrations with enterprise-grade reliability:

  • Self-healing migration engine with automatic retry
  • Automated cutover with health checks and rollback
  • Multi-master replication support
  • Zero-downtime strategies (Blue-Green, Canary, Rolling)
  • Cross-engine migrations (PostgreSQL, MySQL, Oracle, MongoDB)

docs.title: Discover
docs.text:
# Analyze source database
infraiq dataiq discover \
  --source postgresql://user:pass@host:5432/db \
  --output discovery.json

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
# Create migration plan
infraiq dataiq plan \
  --assessment discovery.json \
  --target aurora-postgresql \
  --output migration-plan.json

docs.title: Migrate
docs.text:
# Execute migration with self-healing
infraiq dataiq migrate \
  --plan migration-plan.json \
  --self-heal \
  --auto-cutover

docs.title: Validate
docs.text:
# Validate data integrity
infraiq dataiq validate \
  --source postgresql://source \
  --target postgresql://target

docs.title: Blue-Green
docs.text:
Two identical environments with instant cutover:

infraiq dataiq migrate \
  --plan migration-plan.json \
  --strategy blue-green

docs.title: Canary
docs.text:
Gradual traffic shift with monitoring:

infraiq dataiq migrate \
  --plan migration-plan.json \
  --strategy canary \
  --canary-percent 10

docs.title: Supported Databases
docs.text: Source Target PostgreSQL Aurora PostgreSQL, RDS, Cloud SQL MySQL Aurora MySQL, RDS, Cloud SQL Oracle PostgreSQL (with transformation) MongoDB DocumentDB, Atlas

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• MigrateIQ — Application migration
  • Heroku to AWS Guide

docs.title: MigrateIQ
docs.text: Automated cloud-to-cloud migration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
MigrateIQ automates the entire cloud migration lifecycle:

  • Scans existing infrastructure (Heroku, AWS, GCP, Azure)
  • Maps services intelligently to target cloud providers
  • Generates production-ready Terraform configurations
  • Validates migrations for security and compliance

docs.title: Scan
docs.text:
Discover your current infrastructure:

# Scan Heroku
infraiq migrate scan heroku --app-name my-app --output scan.json

# Scan AWS
infraiq migrate scan aws --region us-east-1 --output scan.json

# Include all apps in a Heroku team
infraiq migrate scan heroku --team my-team --output scan.json

docs.title: Map
docs.text:
Map source services to target provider:

# Map to AWS with defaults
infraiq migrate map scan.json aws --output migration-plan.json

# Use custom preferences
infraiq migrate map scan.json aws \
  --preferences high-availability.yaml \
  --output migration-plan.json

docs.title: Generate
docs.text:
Generate Terraform configurations:

infraiq migrate generate migration-plan.json --output ./terraform

Generated files include:

  • main.tf — Primary resources
  • variables.tf — Input variables
  • outputs.tf — Output values
  • vpc.tf — Network configuration
  • ecs.tf — Container services
  • rds.tf — Database configuration
  • secrets.tf — Secret management

docs.title: Heroku to AWS
docs.text: Heroku AWS (Default) AWS (High Availability) Web Dyno ECS Fargate ECS Fargate + ALB Worker Dyno ECS Task ECS Task + SQS Postgres RDS PostgreSQL Aurora PostgreSQL Redis ElastiCache ElastiCache Multi-AZ Scheduler EventBridge + Lambda EventBridge + Lambda Papertrail CloudWatch Logs CloudWatch + OpenSearch

docs.title: Custom Mappings
docs.text:
Create a preferences file:

# high-availability.yaml
mappings:
  web_dyno:
    service: ecs-fargate
    config:
      desired_count: 3
      cpu: 512
      memory: 1024

  postgres:
    service: aurora-postgresql
    config:
      instance_class: db.r6g.large
      multi_az: true

  redis:
    service: elasticache
    config:
      node_type: cache.r6g.large
      num_cache_nodes: 2

docs.title: Basic Migration
docs.text:
# 1. Scan Heroku app
infraiq migrate scan heroku --app-name production-app

# 2. Map to AWS
infraiq migrate map scan.json aws

# 3. Generate Terraform
infraiq migrate generate migration-plan.json --output ./terraform

# 4. Apply
cd terraform
terraform init
terraform plan
terraform apply

docs.title: Migration with Transformation
docs.text:
Combine with Tessera for simultaneous modernization:

infraiq migrate-and-transform \
  --heroku-app production \
  --target aws \
  --transform \
  --output ./migration

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Scan first — Always verify the scan output before mapping
  2. Review mappings — Check the migration plan before generating
  3. Test in staging — Deploy to a test environment first
  4. Plan cutover — Schedule a maintenance window
  5. Validate after — Use VerifyIQ to scan the new infrastructure

docs.title: Heroku API Errors
docs.text:
# Ensure you're logged in
heroku login

# Check API access
heroku apps

docs.title: Missing Environment Variables
docs.text:
The scan captures env vars but not values. Update terraform.tfvars:

environment_variables = {
  DATABASE_URL = "postgres://..."
  REDIS_URL    = "redis://..."
}

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Heroku to AWS Guide — Complete walkthrough
  • VerifyIQ — Validate your migration
  • DataIQ — Zero-downtime database migration

docs.title: Tools Overview
docs.text: InfraIQ provides seven integrated tools that work together or standalone.

docs.title: The Suite
docs.text: Tool Purpose Status MigrateIQ Cloud-to-cloud migration Production Ready VerifyIQ Security & compliance scanning Production Ready CodifyIQ Infrastructure as Code generation Production Ready ComplyIQ Compliance automation Production Ready DataIQ Database migration Enterprise Ready SecureIQ Secret management Production Ready Tessera Monolith decomposition Production Ready

docs.title: How They Work Together
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[VerifyIQ] -->|Scan| B[Current State]
    B --> C[MigrateIQ]
    B --> D[CodifyIQ]
    B --> E[Tessera]
    C -->|Plan| F[Migration Plan]
    D -->|Generate| G[Terraform]
    E -->|Design| H[Microservices]
    F --> I[ComplyIQ]
    I -->|Validate| J[Compliant Infrastructure]

docs.title: Shared Components
docs.text:
When used together, the tools share:

  • Infrastructure Knowledge Graph — Single source of truth
  • Shared Scanning Engine — Reuse discovery across tools
  • Unified CLI — Consistent command structure
  • Combined Reporting — Complete visibility
  • Cross-Tool Validation — Each tool validates the others

docs.title: MigrateIQ
docs.text:
# Scan source infrastructure
infraiq migrate scan heroku --app-name my-app

# Map to target provider
infraiq migrate map scan.json aws

# Generate Terraform
infraiq migrate generate migration-plan.json --output ./terraform

docs.title: VerifyIQ
docs.text:
# Security scan
infraiq verify scan --provider aws --output report.json

# Analyze report
infraiq verify analyze report.json

# Validate Terraform
infraiq verify validate ./terraform

docs.title: CodifyIQ
docs.text:
# Discover resources
infraiq codify scan aws --region us-east-1 -o scan.json

# Generate Terraform
infraiq codify generate scan.json --output ./terraform

docs.title: ComplyIQ
docs.text:
# Quick compliance check
infraiq complyiq quickscan

# Full SOC2 evidence collection
infraiq complyiq scan --provider aws --framework soc2 --bucket evidence-bucket

docs.title: DataIQ
docs.text:
# Discover database structure
infraiq dataiq discover --source postgresql://... --output discovery.json

# Plan migration
infraiq dataiq plan --assessment discovery.json --target aurora-postgresql

# Execute with self-healing
infraiq dataiq migrate --plan migration-plan.json --self-heal --auto-cutover

docs.title: SecureIQ
docs.text:
# Discover secrets
infraiq secureiq scan --provider heroku --input scan.json --output secrets.yaml

# Audit for compliance
infraiq secureiq audit --manifest secrets.yaml --framework soc2

docs.title: Tessera
docs.text:
# Analyze monolith
infraiq tessera analyze --source . --output analysis.json

# Design microservices
infraiq tessera design --analysis analysis.json --pattern hybrid --output mosaic.yaml

# Generate service scaffolds
infraiq tessera craft --mosaic mosaic.yaml --framework fastapi --output ./services

docs.title: When to Use Each Tool
docs.text: Scenario Tool Migrating from Heroku to AWS MigrateIQ Security audit before migration VerifyIQ Converting ClickOps to GitOps CodifyIQ Preparing for SOC2 audit ComplyIQ Upgrading PostgreSQL version DataIQ Mapping secrets before migration SecureIQ Breaking up a monolith Tessera Complete modernization All of them!

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• MigrateIQ — Deep dive into migrations
  • Quick Start — Your first migration
  • Heroku to AWS Guide — Complete walkthrough

docs.title: SecureIQ
docs.text: Secret discovery and management for migrations.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
SecureIQ helps you manage secrets during migrations:

  • Discovers all secrets without reading values
  • Classifies secrets by type and criticality
  • Maps dependencies between secrets and services
  • Generates migration checklists
  • Validates compliance requirements

docs.title: Scan
docs.text:
# Discover secrets from infrastructure scan
infraiq secureiq scan \
  --provider heroku \
  --input scan.json \
  --output secrets.yaml

docs.title: Audit
docs.text:
# Check compliance requirements
infraiq secureiq audit \
  --manifest secrets.yaml \
  --framework soc2

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
# Generate migration checklist
infraiq secureiq checklist \
  --manifest secrets.yaml \
  --target aws \
  --output checklist.md

docs.title: Validate
docs.text:
# Validate migration readiness
infraiq secureiq validate \
  --manifest secrets.yaml \
  --migration-plan plan.json

docs.title: Secret Types
docs.text: Type Examples Database DATABASE_URL, POSTGRES_PASSWORD API Keys STRIPE_API_KEY, SENDGRID_KEY OAuth GITHUB_CLIENT_SECRET Encryption SECRET_KEY_BASE, JWT_SECRET Service AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY

docs.title: Privacy
docs.text:
Zero Data Access

SecureIQ never reads secret values. It only analyzes metadata, variable names, and patterns to classify secrets.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• MigrateIQ — Use with migrations
  • ComplyIQ — Compliance validation

docs.title: Tessera
docs.text: AI-powered monolith to microservices transformation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Tessera intelligently decomposes monoliths into microservices:

  • AI-powered service boundary detection using LLMs
  • Zero-data access database analysis (metadata only)
  • Multi-language support (Python, JavaScript, Ruby, Go, Java)
  • Domain-driven decomposition using DDD principles
  • Confidence scoring on all recommendations

docs.title: Analyze
docs.text:
# Analyze monolith structure
infraiq tessera analyze \
  --source ./myapp \
  --heroku-app production \
  --output analysis.json

# With AI analysis
infraiq tessera analyze \
  --source . \
  --use-ai \
  --output analysis.json

docs.title: Design
docs.text:
# Design microservices architecture
infraiq tessera design \
  --analysis analysis.json \
  --pattern hybrid \
  --output mosaic.yaml

# Interactive mode
infraiq tessera design \
  --analysis analysis.json \
  --interactive \
  --output mosaic.yaml

docs.title: Craft
docs.text:
# Generate service scaffolds
infraiq tessera craft \
  --mosaic mosaic.yaml \
  --framework fastapi \
  --include-docker \
  --include-ci \
  --output ./services

docs.title: Validate
docs.text:
# Validate the architecture
infraiq tessera validate \
  --mosaic mosaic.yaml \
  --check dependencies,data,performance

docs.title: Domain-Driven (DDD)
docs.text:
Identifies bounded contexts and aggregates:

infraiq tessera design --pattern domain

docs.title: Data-Driven
docs.text:
Based on database relationships and access patterns:

infraiq tessera design --pattern data

docs.title: Team-Oriented
docs.text:
Conway's Law alignment with team structure:

infraiq tessera design --pattern team

docs.title: Hybrid (Recommended)
docs.text:
Combines multiple strategies:

infraiq tessera design --pattern hybrid

docs.title: One-Command Migration + Transformation
docs.text:
infraiq migrate-and-transform \
  --heroku-app production \
  --target aws \
  --transform \
  --output ./migration

This single command:

  1. Scans your Heroku app
  2. Analyzes for microservices boundaries
  3. Designs the service architecture
  4. Generates migration plan
  5. Creates service scaffolds
  6. Produces Terraform/Kubernetes configs

docs.title: Generated Output
docs.text:
./services/
├── user-service/
│   ├── src/
│   ├── Dockerfile
│   ├── requirements.txt
│   └── README.md
├── order-service/
│   ├── src/
│   ├── Dockerfile
│   └── ...
├── k8s/
│   ├── user-service.yaml
│   └── order-service.yaml
└── docker-compose.yaml

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Monolith Decomposition Guide
  • MigrateIQ — Combine with migration

docs.title: VerifyIQ
docs.text: Infrastructure verification and security scanning.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
VerifyIQ validates your infrastructure for:

  • Security — Vulnerabilities and misconfigurations
  • Cost — Optimization opportunities
  • Drift — Differences between code and reality
  • Compliance — Best practice adherence

docs.title: Scan
docs.text:
# Scan AWS infrastructure
infraiq verify scan --provider aws --output report.json

# Scan specific regions
infraiq verify scan --provider aws --region us-east-1,us-west-2

# Scan Heroku
infraiq verify scan --provider heroku --output report.json

docs.title: Analyze
docs.text:
# View scan results
infraiq verify analyze report.json

# Filter by severity
infraiq verify analyze report.json --severity high,critical

# Filter by category
infraiq verify analyze report.json --category security

docs.title: Validate
docs.text:
# Validate Terraform configurations
infraiq verify validate ./terraform

# Validate with custom rules
infraiq verify validate ./terraform --rules ./custom-rules.yaml

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
• Public S3 buckets
  • Open security groups
  • Unencrypted databases
  • Missing MFA
  • Overly permissive IAM roles

docs.title: Cost
docs.text:
• Unused resources
  • Oversized instances
  • Missing reserved instances
  • Unattached volumes

docs.title: Reliability
docs.text:
• Single AZ deployments
  • Missing backups
  • No auto-scaling
  • Missing health checks

docs.title: Compliance
docs.text:
• SOC2 requirements
  • HIPAA requirements
  • PCI-DSS requirements

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
{
  "summary": {
    "critical": 2,
    "high": 5,
    "medium": 12,
    "low": 8
  },
  "findings": [
    {
      "severity": "critical",
      "category": "security",
      "resource": "arn:aws:s3:::my-bucket",
      "title": "S3 bucket is publicly accessible",
      "description": "The bucket allows public read access",
      "remediation": "Remove public access in bucket policy"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• ComplyIQ — Compliance automation
  • CodifyIQ — Convert to IaC
